titleStmt.title: Miscellaneous extracts in prose and verse. Calculated for the amusement of the humerous [sic] and gay, as well as for the instruction and service of the enquiring and busy world. : To which are added, a number of important questions; which questions, whoever will effectually and satisfactorily answer, shall be entitled to one hundred dollars reward on demand, from Dan. C. Melville.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 50 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 36 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

Calculated for the amusement of the humerous [sic] and gay, as well as for the instruction and service of the enquiring and busy world. : To which are added, a number of important questions; which questions, whoever will effectually and satisfactorily answer, shall be entitled to one hundred dollars reward on demand, from Dan. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: MISCELLANEOUS EXTRACTS IN PROSE and VERSE. CALCULATED FOR THE AMUSEMENT OF THE HUMEROUS AND GAY, AS WELL AS FOR THE INSTRUCTION AND SERVICE OF THE ENQUIRING AND BUSY WORLD.

TO WHICH ARE ADDED, A NUMBER OF IMPORTANT QUESTIONS; WHICH QUESTIONS, WHOEVER WILL EFFECTUALLY AND SATISFACTORILY ANSWER, SHALL BE ENTITLED TO ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS REWARD ON DEMAND, FROM DAN. C. MELVILLE.

div.head: NECESSARY HINTS TO THOSE THAT WOULD BE RICH.
div.p: THE u≈øe of money is all the advantage there is in having money.
For ≈øix pounds a year you may have the u≈øe of an hundred pounds, provided you are a man of known prudence and hone≈øty.
He that ≈øpends a groat a day idly, ≈øpends idly above ≈øix pounds a year, which is the u≈øe of one hundred pounds.
He that wa≈øtes idly a groat's worth of time per day, one day with another, wa≈øtes the privilege of one hundred pounds per day.
He that idly lo≈øes five ≈øhillings worth of time, lo≈øes five ≈øhillings, and might as prudently throw five ≈øhillings into the ≈øea.

He that lo≈øes five ≈øhillings, not only lo≈øes that ≈øum‚ñ™ but all the advantage that might be made by turning it in dealing, which, by the time that a young man becomes old, will amount to a con≈øiderable ≈øum of mony‚ñ™

Again: He that ≈øells upon credit, a≈øks a price for
what he ≈øells equivalent to the principal and intere≈øt of his money for the time he is to be kept out of it; therefore he that buys upon credit, pays intere≈øt for what he buys; and he that pays ready money, might let that money out to u≈øe: ≈øo that he that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes any thing he has bought, pays intere≈øt for the u≈øe of it.

Yet, in buying goods, it is be≈øt to pay ready money, becau≈øe, he that ≈øells upon credit, expects to lo≈øe five per cent, by bad debts; therefore he charges, on all he ≈øells upon credit, an advance that ≈øhall make up that deficiency.
Tho≈øe who pay for what they buy upon credit, pay their ≈øhare of this advance.
He that pays ready money, e≈øcapes, or may e≈øcape that charge.

l.hi: A penny ≈øav'd is two pence clear;
A pin a day's a groat a year.

div.head: THE WAY TO MAKE MONEY PLENTY IN EVERY MAN's POCKET.
div.p:
AT this time, when the general complaint is that‚Äî"Money is ≈øcarce," it will be an act of kindne≈øs to inform the moneyle≈øs how they may reinforce their pockets. I will acquaint them with the true ≈øecret
of money-catching‚Äîthe certain way to fill empty pur≈øes‚Äîand how to keep them always full. Two ≈øimple rules-well ob≈øerved, will do the bu≈øine≈øs.
Fir≈øt, let hone≈øty and indu≈øtry be thy con≈øtant companions; and,
Secondly, ≈øpend one penny le≈øs than thy clear gains.

Then ≈øhall thy hide bound pocket ≈øoon begin to thrive, and will never again cry with the empty bellyache: neither will creditors in≈øult thee, nor want oppre≈øs, nor hunger bite, nor nakedne≈øs freeze thee.

The whole hemi≈øphere will ≈øhine brighter, and plea≈øure ≈øpring up in every corner of thy heart. Now therefore, embrace the≈øe rules and be happy. Bani≈øh the bleak winds of ≈øorrow from thy mind, and live independant. Then ≈øhalt thou be a man, and not hide thy face at the approach of the rich, nor ≈øuffer the pain of feeling little when the ≈øons of fortune walk at thy right hand: for indepednency, whether with little or much, is good fortune, and placeth thee on even ground with the proude≈øt of the golden fleece. Oh then, be wi≈øe, and let indu≈øtry walk with thee in the morning, and attend thee untill thou reache≈øt the evening hour for re≈øt. Let hone≈øty be as the breath of thy ≈øoul, and never forget to have a penny when all thy expen≈øes are enumerated and paid: then ≈øhalt thou
reach the point of happine≈øs, and independance ≈øhall be thy ≈øhield and buckler, thy helmet and crown; then ≈øhall thy ≈øoul walk upright, nor ≈øtooop to the ≈øilken wretch becau≈øe he hath riches, nor pocket an abu≈øe becau≈øe the hand which offers it wears a ring ≈øet with diamonds.

div.head: THE WHISTLE. A TRUE STORY.
div.p: WHen I was a child, at ≈øeven years old, my friends on a holiday filled my pockets with coppers, I went directly to a ≈øhop where they ≈øold toys for children; and being charmed with the ≈øound of a whi≈øtle, that I met by the way in the hands of another boy, I volluntarily offered him all my money for one. I then came home, and went whi≈øtling all over the hou≈øe, much plea≈øed with my whi≈øtle, but di≈øturbing all the family, my brothers and ≈øi≈øters, and cou≈øins, under≈øtanding the bargain I had made, told me I had given four times as much for it as it was worth. This put me in mind what good things I might have bought with the re≈øt of my money; and they laughed at me ≈øo much for my folly that I cried with vexation; and the reflection gave me more chagrin than the whi≈øtle gave me plea≈øure.

This however was afterwards of u≈øe to me, the impre≈ø≈øions continuing on my mind; ≈øo that often when I was tempted to buy ≈øome unnece≈ø≈øary thing, I ≈øaid to my≈øelf don't give too much for the whi≈øtle; and ≈øo I ≈øaved my money.
As I grew up, came into the world, and ob≈øerved the actions of men, I thought I met with many, very many, who gave too much for the whi≈øtle.

When I ≈øaw any one too ambitious of court favours, ≈øacrifice his time in attendance on levees, his repo≈øe, his liberty, his virtue, and perhaps his friends to attain it, I have ≈øaid to my≈øelf, this man gives too much for his whi≈øtle.

When I ≈øaw another fond of popularity, con≈øtantly employing him≈øelf in political bu≈øtles, neglecting his own affairs, and ruining them by that neglect: he pays indeed, ≈øays I, too much for his whi≈øtle.

If I knew a mi≈øer, who gave up every kind of comfortable living, all the plea≈øure of doing good to others, all the e≈øteem of his fellow citizens, and the joys of benevolent friend≈øhip, for the ≈øake of accumulating wealth: poor man ≈øays I, you do indeed pay too much for your whi≈øtle.

If I fee one fond of fine clothing, fine furniture, fine equipage, and above his fortune, for which he contracts debts, and ends his career in pri≈øon, alas, ≈øay I, he pays dear, very dear, for his whi≈øtle.
When I ≈øee a beautiful, ≈øweet tempered, girl married to an ill-natured brute of a hu≈øband: what a pity it is, ≈øays I, that ≈øhe has paid ≈øo much for a whi≈øtle.

In ≈øhort, I concieve, that great part of the mi≈øeries of mankind were brought upon them by the fal≈øe e≈øtimates they had made of the value of things, and by their giving too much for their whi≈øtle.

div.head: LIFE.
div.p: AUGUSTUS, a few moments before his death, a≈øked his friends who ≈øtood about him, if they thought he had acted his part well; and upon recieving ≈øuch an≈øwer as was due to his extraordinary merit‚ÄîLet me then, ≈øays he, go off the ≈øtage with your applau≈øe, u≈øing the expre≈ø≈øion with which the Roman actors made their exit at the conclu≈øion of a dramatic piece.

I could wi≈øh that men, while they are in the health, would con≈øider well the nature of the part they are engaged in, and what figure it will make in the minds of tho≈øe they leave behind them: whether it was worth coming into the world for; whether it be ≈øuitable to a rea≈øonable being; in ≈øhort, whether it appears graceful in this life, or will turn to advantage in the next. Let the ≈øycophant, or buffoon, the ≈øatiri≈øt,
or the good companion, con≈øider with him≈øelf, when his body ≈øhall be laid in the grave: and his ≈øoul pa≈øs into another ≈øtate of exi≈øtence, how much it would redound to his prai≈øe to have it ≈øaid of him, that no man in England eat better, that he had an admirable talent at turning his friends into ridicule, that no body out‚ñ™ did him at an-ill-natured je≈øt, or that he never went to bed before he had di≈øpatched his third bottle.

The≈øe are, however, very common funeral orations, and elogiums on decea≈øed per≈øons who have acted among mankind with ≈øome figure and reputation. But if we look into the bulk of our ≈øpecies, there are ≈øuch as are not likely to be remembered a moment after their di≈øappearance. They leave behind them no traces of their exi≈øtence, but are forgotten as though they had never been. They are neither wanted by the poor, regretted by the rich, nor celebrated by the learned. They are neither mi≈ø≈øed in the common-wealth, nor lamented by private per≈øons.

Their actions are of no ≈øignificancy to mankind, and might have been performed by creatures of much le≈øs dignity than tho≈øe who are di≈øtingui≈øhed by the faculty of rea≈øon. An eminent French author ≈øpeaks ≈øomewhere to the following purpo≈øe; I have often ≈øeen from my chamber-window two noble creatures, both of them of an erect countenance, and endowed with
rea≈øon.‚ÄîThe≈øe two intellectual beings are employed from morning to night, in rubbing two ≈ømooth ≈øtones one upon another; that is, as the vulgar phra≈øe is, in poli≈øhing marble.

My friend, Sir Andrew Freeport, as we were ≈øitting in the club la≈øt night, gave us an account of a ≈øober citizen, who died a few days ≈øince. This hone≈øt man being of greater con≈øequence in his own thoughts than in the eye of the world, had for ≈øome years pa≈øt kept a journal of his life. Sir Andrew, ≈øhowed us one week of it. Since the occurrences ≈øet down in it mark out ≈øuch a road of action as that I have been ≈øpeaking of, I ≈øhall pre≈øent my readers with a faithful copy of it; after having fir≈øt informed him, that the decea≈øed per≈øon had in his youth been bred to trade, but finding him≈øelf not ≈øo well turned for bu≈øine≈øs, he had for ≈øeveral years pa≈øt lived altogether upon a moderate annuity.
Monday, eight o'clock. I put on my clothes, and walked into the parlour.
Nine o'clock ditto. Tied my knee ≈øtrings; and wa≈øhed my hands.
Hours ten, eleven, and twelve. Smoaked three pipes of Virginia. Read the Supplement, and Daily Courant. Things go ill in the north. Mr. Ni≈øby's opinion thereupon.
One o'clock in the afternoon. Chid Ralph for mi≈ølaying my tobacco box.
Two o'clock. Sat down to dinner. Mem. too many plumbs and no ≈øuet.
From three to four. Took my afternoon's nap.
From four to ≈øix. Walked into the fields. Wind S. S. E.
From ≈øix to ten. At the club. Mr. Ni≈øby's opinion about the peace.
Ten o'clock. Went to bed, ≈ølept ≈øound.
Tue≈øday being holy-day, eight o'clock. Ro≈øe as u≈øual.
Nine o'clock. Wa≈øhed hands and face, ≈øhaved, put on my double ≈øoaled-≈øhoes.
Ten, eleven, twelve. Took a walk to I≈ølington.
One. Took a pot of Mother Cob's Mild.
Between two and three. Returned, dined on a knuckle of veal and bacon. Mem. Sprouts wanting.
Three. Nap as u≈øual.
From four to ≈øix. Coffee hou≈øe. Read the news. A di≈øh of twi≈øt. Grand Vizier ≈øtrangled.
From ≈øix to ten. At the club. Mr. Ni≈øby's account of the Great Turk.
Ten. Dream of the grand Vizier. Broken ≈øleep.
Wende≈øday, eight o'clock. Tongue of my ≈øhoe buckle broke. Wa≈øhed hands but not face.
Nine. Paid off the butcher's bill. Mem. To be allowed for the la≈øt leg of mutton.

Ten, eleven. „Äà‚óä„Äâ
At the coffee hou≈øe. More work in the north. Stranger in a black wig, a≈øked me how ≈øtocks went.
From eleven, to one. Walked in the fields. Wind to the South
From one, to two. Smoaked a pipe and an half.
Two. Dinner as u≈øual. Stomach good.
Three. Nap broke by the falling of a „Äà‚óä„Äâ di≈øh. Mem. Cook maid in love, and grown carele≈øs.
From four to ≈øix. At the coffee hou≈øe. Advice from Smyrna. That the grand Vizier was fir≈øt of all ≈øtrangled, and afterwards beheaded.
Six o'clock in the evening. Was half an hour in the club before any body el≈øe came. Mr. Ni≈øby of opinion that the grand Vizier was not ≈øtrangled the ≈øixth in≈øtant.
Ten at night. Went to bed‚ñ™ Slept without waking 'till nine next morning.
Thur≈øday, nine o'clock. Staid within, 'till two o'clock for Sir Timothy; who did not bring me my annuity according to his promi≈øe.
Two in the afternoon. Sat down to dinner, lo≈øs of appetite. Small beer four. Beef over-corned.
Three. Could not take my nap
Four and five. Gave Ralph a box on the ear. Turned off my cook maid. Sent a me≈ø≈øenger to Sir Timothy. Mem. I did not go to the club to night. Went to bed at nine o'clock.
Friday. Pa≈ø≈øed the morning in meditation upon Sir Timothy, who was with me a quarter before twelve.
Twelve o'clock, Bought a new head to my ‚Ä¢ ane, and a tongue to my buckle. Drank a gla≈øs of purl to recover appetite.
Two and three. Dined and ≈ølept well.
From four to ≈øix. Went to the coffee hou≈øe. Met Mr. Ni≈øby there. Smoked ≈øeveral pipes. Mr. Ni≈øby of opinion that tacid coffee is bad for the head.
Six o'clock. At the club as Steward. Sat late.
Twelve o'clock. Went to bed, dreamt that I drank ≈ømall beer with the Vizier.
Saturday. Waked at eleven, walked in the fields. Wind N. E.
Twelve. Caught in a ≈øhower.
One in the afternoon. Returned home and dried my≈øelf.
Two. Mr. Ni≈øby dined with me. Fir≈øt cour≈øe, marrow bones, ≈øecond, ox che ‚Ä¢ k, with a bottle of Brooks & Hillier.
Three o'clock. Over≈ølept my≈øelf.
Six. Went to the club, „Äà‚óä„Äâ to have fallen into the gutter. Grand Vizier certainly dead, &c.

I que≈øtion not but the readers will be ≈øurpri≈øed to find the above-mentioned journali≈øt taking ≈øo much care of a life that was filled with ≈øuch incon≈øiderable actions, and received ≈øo very ≈ømall improvements; and yet, if we look into the behavior of many whom we daily conver≈øe with, we ≈øhall find mo≈øt of our hours are taken up in tho≈øe three important articles of eating, drinking and ≈øleeping.

I do not ≈øuppo≈øe that a man lo≈øes his time, who is not engaged in public affairs, or in an illu≈øtrious cour≈øe of action. On the contrary, I believe our hours may very often be more profitably laid out in ≈øuch tran≈øactions as make no figure in the world, than in ≈øuch as are apt to draw upon them the attention of mankind. One may become wi≈øer and better by ≈øeveral methods of employing ones-≈øelf in ≈øecrecy and ≈øilence, and do what is laudable without noi≈øe or o≈øtentation. I would, however, recommend to every one of my readers, the keeping a journal of their lives for one week, and ≈øetting down punctually their whole ≈øeries of employments during that ≈øpace of time.

This kind of Self examination would give them a true ≈øtate of them≈øelves, and incline them to con≈øider ≈øeriou≈øly what they are about. One day would rectify the mi≈øtakes of another, and make a man weigh all tho≈øe indifferent actions, which, though they are ea≈øier forgotten, mu≈øt certainly be accounted for.

div.head: SEVERAL RELATIONS touching the nature of tho≈øe perpetual La ‚Ä¢ ps which have continued burning for many centuries together, &c. (From the Briti≈øh Magazine.)
div.p: SINCE you have entertained your readers with ≈øeveral curious pieces, which refer to nature and art, I doubt not, but the ≈øub≈øequent pa≈ø≈øages of tho≈øe perpetual lamps which have continued burning (in the ≈øepulchres of the Ancients) for many centuries together, without any fre≈øh ≈øupply, will prove acceptable.

All fire, but e≈øpecially flame, ≈øays philo≈øophers is of an active and ≈øtirring nature, and cannot po≈ø≈øibly ≈øub≈øi≈øt without motion: Now there are ≈øeveral authors who have treated of this ≈øubject by the by, tho' none, ≈øays the learned and judicious Bi≈øhop Wilkins, that have writ any thing to the purpo≈øe, (except the ingenious Fortunius Licetus) from whom we ≈øhall beg leave to borrow ≈øome undeniable proofs, which we hope will be ≈øuitable to our pre≈øent enquiry.

Fir≈øt then that there hath been ≈øuch lamps, St. Au≈øtin mentions one of them in a temple dedicated to Venus which was alway expo≈øed to the open weather, and could never be extingui≈øhed; Pamyrollus mentions a lamp found in his time, in the ≈øepulchre of Tulli ‚Ä¢ , Cicero's daughter, which had continued there for 1550 years, but was pre≈øently extingui≈øhed by the admi≈ø≈øion
of new air. And 'tis commonly reported of Cedrenus, that in Ju≈øtinian's time there was another burning lamp found in an old wall at Antioch; which had remained for above 500 years, there being a crucifix placed by it; hence it appears, that they were in u≈øe with the primitive Chri≈øtians.

But more e≈øpecially remarkable is that of Olybius, which had continued burning for 1500 years: the relation is this: "As a ru≈øtic was digging the ground by Padua, he found an urn, in which there was another urn, and in this a le≈ø≈øer, with a lamp clearly burning; on each ≈øide of it there were two other ve≈ø≈øels, both of them full of a pure liquor the one of gold, the other of ≈øilver". Hence we may probably conjecture, that it was ≈øome chemical ≈øecret by which it was contrived. Bapti≈øta Porta, tells us of another lamp, burning in an old marble ≈øepulchre belonging to ≈øome of the Ancient Romans, enclo≈øed in a gla≈øs vial, found in his time, about the year 1550, in the I≈øb Ni≈øis which had been buried there before our Savior's incarnation.
In the tomb of Pallas the Areadian, who was ≈ølain by Turnus in the Trojan war, there was found another burning lamp.

In the year of our Lord 1401, whence it would ≈øeem that it had continued there for above 2600 years; and being taken out, it continued burning, notwith≈øtanding either wind or water, with which ≈øome
≈øtrove to quench it, nor could it be extingui≈øhed till they had ≈øpilt the liquor in it. Ludouicus Vives tells us of another lamp that continued burning for 1050 years, which was found a little before his time. There is another relation of a certain man, who, upon diging ≈øomewhat deep in the ground, met with ≈øomething like a door, having a wall on each hand of it, from which he cleared the earth; he farved open the door, and there di≈øcovered a fair vault, toward the farther ≈øide of which was the ≈øtatue of a man in armour, ‚Ä¢ iting by a table, leaning upon his left arm, and holding a ≈øceptre in his right hand, with a lamp burning before him; the floor of this vault being ≈øo contrived, that upon the fir≈øt ≈øtep into it, the ≈øtatute erected it≈øelf from its leaning po≈øture, upon the ≈øecond ≈øtep, it lifted up the ≈øceptre to ≈øtrike, and before the man could approach near the lamp, to take hold of it, the ≈øtatute ≈øtruck and broke it to pieces; ≈øuch care was had that it might not be taken away, nor di≈øcovered; and the learned and judicious Mr. Cambden, in his de≈øcription of York≈øhire, page, 572, ≈øpeaking of the tomb of Con≈øtantius Clorus, broken up in tho≈øe times, mentions ≈øuch a lamp to be found within it.

It is evident that there are ≈øeveral other relations to this purpo≈øe, be≈øides the≈øe above mentioned, notwith≈øtanding the oppo≈øite opinions of our adver≈øaries, by which it clearly appears that there have been ≈øuch
lamps which have remained burning for ≈øeveral centuries together, &c, and there are ≈øeveral opinions why the Ancients were ≈øo careful in pre≈øerving them, ≈øome of which we ≈øhall here exhibit.

1≈øt. Some think it to be an expre≈ø≈øion of their belief, concerning the ≈øoul's immortality after its departure out of the body; a lamp among the Egyptians being the hyerogliphick of life: and therefore that they that could not procure ≈øuch lamps, were yet careful to have the image and repre≈øentation of them engraved upon their tombs. Others conceive them by way of gratitude to tho≈øe infernal deities, who took the charge and cu≈øtody of their body's when dead, remaining always with them in their tombs, and were therefore called Dii Manes.

Others, that the≈øe lamps were only intended to make their ≈øepulchres more plea≈øant, that they may not ≈øeem to be impri≈øoned in a di≈ømal and uncomfortable place. True indeed! a dead body cannot be ≈øen≈øible of the light, no more could it of it's want of burial; yet the ≈øame in≈øtinct which did excite it to the de≈øire of one, did al≈øo occa≈øion the other.

Licetus concludes this ancient cu≈øtom to have a double end; 1≈øt. politick, for the di≈øtinction of ≈øuch as were noble-born; hence it was u≈øual for the nobles among≈øt the romans, to take ≈øpecial care in their la≈øt wills, that they might have a lamp in their own monuments,
and for that purpo≈øe gave liberty to their ≈ølaves on this condition, that they ≈øhould be watchful in maintaining and pre≈øerving it. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d. Natural, to pre≈øerve the body from darkne≈øs;‚Äîof which tho' there have been ≈øo many ≈øundry kinds; and ≈øeveral ways to make them, (≈øome being able to re≈øi≈øt any violence of weathers, others being ea≈øily extingui≈øhed by any little alteration of the air, ≈øome being enclo≈øed round about with gla≈øs, others being open,) yet they are all of them utterly peri≈øhed among≈øt the ruins of Time, and tho≈øe who are ver≈øed in the ≈øearch after them, have only recovered ≈øuch dark conjectures, as are generally rejected and di≈øbelieved by the litterati of a brighter age; So I ≈øhall ≈øay no more on this head, but conclude with that of the poet, viz,
‚ÄîSi quid novi≈øti rectius i≈øtis
Candidus impe≈øti, ≈øi non his utere mecum. HORACE.

closer.signed: I am ≈øir your con≈øtant reader: and humble ≈øervant. R. Hulfe.

lg.l: WHEN charming Stella ≈øpeaks the li≈øt'ning throng
All wrapt in mute attention mo≈øt profound,
Catch the enchanting accents from her tongue,
And ≈øofte≈øt, thrilling notes our ears ≈øurround.
When Stella's ≈øilent, ≈øtill ≈øhe breathes around
Odours, which cannot be by words expre≈øt,
Thus, fragrant gales the enraptur'd ≈øoul confound,
Wing'd from the ≈øhores of Araba the ble≈øt.
Were I ≈øole monarch of this pond'rous ball,
In all the dazzling glare of pomp array'd,
Gladly I'd quit the gaudy, tu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing all
Ble≈øt in a Cottage with my heavenly maid.
BEAUTY and wit the mighty maker gave
To woman, to reward the great and brave.
To wing their winter hours, and ≈øooth their cares,
And ≈øweeten the fatigues of camps and wars.
Beauty and wit and every charming grace
Which brightens and adorns the mind and face,
The power creating has in her expre≈ø≈ø'd
And him with every many virtue ble≈øt.
The plea≈øure beauty gives is an exce≈øs,
And nothing in exce≈øs, can always plea≈øe,
Things exqui≈øitely fine will ≈øoone≈øt cloy
And man's too apt to ≈øurfeit e'en of joy;
But then the rapture's la≈øting when 'tis join'd
With wit the winning beauty of the mind.
Wit warms ≈øociety by plea≈øing ≈øtrife,
And quickens and refines the joys of life.
Wit's always gay, agreeable and new.
And plea≈øes when it bites, and when it flatters too
Their mutual aid they to each other lend
Beauty is Wit's and wit is beauty's friend:
But when with virtue they together ≈øhine,
The tran≈øport is eternal and divine.

div.head: The Protector's advice to ALGERNON SIDNEY Communicated by Dr. Rawlin≈øon. (A very important article from the ≈øtudent.)
div.p: The following curious anecdote was found indor≈øed on paper ≈øigned Alg. Sidney.
The Protector's advice to me, when I went from him to the King of Sweden in Poland; which I write from his own detailing, and the alteration in the ≈øecond particular is his own hand.
I. IF you would not mi≈øcarry in this bu≈øine≈øs, know fir≈øt, that all publique bu≈øine≈ø≈øes‚ñ™ and private too, pro≈øper and ≈øucceed only as God is plea≈øed to determine them.
II. And that therefore the greate≈øt wi≈ødom in them that are employed about bu≈øine≈ø≈øe lies in this, that they ≈øeek to be accepted with God, which no man is, but by Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

III. That there be a denial of mans own abilities, and that work be undertaken with humility and meekne≈øs of ≈øpirit, and that one be ≈øwift to hear, and ≈ølow to ≈øpeak, well under≈øtanding before he an≈øwer.

IV. That a man in his own conver≈øations, as he would have a ble≈ø≈øing, ab≈øtaine from all manner of evil, and con≈øtantly, with all earne≈øtne≈øs and truth of heart, crye to God for a ble≈ø≈øing‚ñ™ ≈øeeing he di≈øpo≈øes the i≈ø≈øue of things all bu≈øine≈ø≈øes as he plea≈øes.

div.head: From a ≈øtate≈øman retired from Court, to my Lord ‚Äî. In commendation of a country life. (From the Univer≈øal Magazine.)
div.p:
COULD I think you capable of in≈øulting me in this
my ab≈øolute retreat from all the polite and modi≈øh part of ≈øociety, when you reque≈øt from me a detail of my ≈øolitary amu≈øements; no one ≈øhould exact a more ≈øevere ≈øatisfaction: but, as I have no rea≈øon to que≈øtion your former friend≈øhip, I ≈øhall, with my u≈øual undi≈øgui≈øed openne≈øs, lay before you my manner of life, and how it is agreeable to one of my years, worn out with the fatigues of the ≈øtate, and cloy'd with the ways of the world.

I never was ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of my own dignity; ab≈øtract from bu≈øine≈øs or diver≈øion, my mind retires within it≈øelf, where it finds trea≈øures, till now, undi≈øcovered; capacities formed for infinite objects, de≈øires that ≈øtretch them≈øelves beyond the limits of this wide creation, in ≈øearch of the great Original of life and plea≈øure. I mu≈øt tell you my Lord, that I find new powers exerting their energy, and employed in ≈øuch exerci≈øe, to which, till now, I have been a ≈øtranger.‚ÄîHow oft have You and I rallied the remembrance of our religious duties, and put his ≈øacred truths on a level with the poet's ro≈øy bowers, myrtle ≈øhades and ely≈ø≈øian fields? But now I am convinced, that the ≈øoil is immortal and capable of cele≈øtial joys, and triumph in the privileges of my own being;‚ÄîI rejoice to think, that the moment I began to exi≈øt, I entered on an eternal ≈øtate, and commenced a duration, that ≈øhall run paralel to that of the ≈øupreme and ≈øelf-exi≈øtent mind.‚ÄîThis pro≈øpect animates
me with a divine ambition, and ca≈øts a reproach on all created glory, which we have been ≈øo long and ≈øo anxiou≈øly looking after. The world vani≈øheth; it's charms and ≈øoft allurements are no more; a vail is ca≈øt on mortal beauty; the ≈øpell is broken, the enchantment di≈ø≈øolved, and though I am every where ≈øurrounded with cau≈øele≈øs enemies, nothing gives me ≈øo great trouble as the lo≈øs of ≈øo much time ≈øpent in the pur≈øuit of peri≈øhable objects. Perchance you may ≈ømile, and take this for an imaginary triumph, or ≈øort of cowardly in≈øult, in the ab≈øence of an enemy: and may think my contempt of grandeur appears with an ill grace, in one that enjoys a con≈øiderable e≈øtate, a grand equipage, and many other tokens of his ≈øovreign favour, for the ≈øervices done to his king and country.

But this, my lord, is what has given me a ju≈øt opinion of the world, and of my≈øelf: a con≈øtant ≈øeries of ≈øucce≈øs and pro≈øperity, has convinced me, that the whole creation cannot make me ble≈ø≈øed. My ambitious de≈øigns have never been di≈øappointed: I have been ≈øo vain to apply to my own power that awful ≈øentence By me kings reign.‚ÄîIn love I have always been fortunate. But whatever plea≈øure I pur≈øued, the enjoyment always undecieved me, or di≈øgu≈øted me.‚ÄîSometimes I was too wi≈øe, ≈øometimes too capricious to be plea≈øed‚ñ™‚ÄîI have tried all the vanities below the ≈øun; and there is le≈øt no novelty to flatter me. I know the
utmo≈øt that beauty and greatne≈øs can give, and am cured of love and ambition by experimental evidence.

Your Lord≈øhip has been witne≈øs to many of tho≈øe truths which I recollect in this ≈øeat of retirement. You cannot forget Eu≈øtatia; the admired Eu≈øtatia, in who≈øe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions my youthful days promi≈øed them≈øelves la≈øting joys.‚ÄîHow did I adore her! You can tell with what eagerne≈øs and anxiety I pur≈øued her virtue. But her yielding beauty, by granting my de≈øires, lo≈øt my e≈øteem; her charms vani≈øhed, her wit was impertinance, and her artifice di≈øgu≈øted me: and this, in a great mea≈øure, put a period to my gallantries.‚Äî

I could thence forward look upon women, without any temptation to idolatry.‚ÄîBalls and a≈ø≈øemblies, dancing and dre≈øs, were no longer the ≈øubject of my ≈øerious application: and I yielded an implicit a≈ø≈øent to tho≈øe petit maitres, who≈øe talents lie in di≈øcu≈ø≈øing the important controver≈øies, who ≈øings be≈øt at the opera' performs be≈øt at the play-hou≈øes, entertains us more agreeably at Vauxhall and Ranelagh‚ñ™ or who ≈øupplies the town be≈øt with Ma≈øquerade dre≈ø≈øes, when they are a≈øhamed to turn fools in their u≈øual habit.

But the≈øe ≈øoft follies were only di≈øcarded for more ≈øpacious vanities.‚ÄîDi≈øtinction and power.‚ÄîTitles and equipage now fill my thoughts‚ÄîAmbition now took full po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of my ≈øoul‚ÄîI clothed my≈øelf with patrioti≈øm‚ñ™ and as the circum≈øtances of the times concerned with my ≈øcheme, „Äà‚óä„Äâ pre≈øently harrangued my≈øelf into e≈øteem‚ñ™ and‚ñ™‚ÄîYou mu≈øt remember that remarkable
debate, by a well-timed oppo≈øition and con≈øtancy. Made my adver≈øaries think it worth their while to gain me over at any rate.‚ÄîFrom ≈øuch beginnings, I reached the envied height, and made my≈øelf gloriou≈øly mi≈øerable.‚ÄîI jumped into the ≈øaddle where I expected the con≈øummation of all my wi≈øhes, but this very period, from whence I hoped to date my happine≈øs, began with di≈øtru≈øt and anxiety.

For≈øaken by my patriot friends, I found my≈øelf ≈øurrounded with flatterers and mercenary dependants; and my ≈øleep, as well as my daily attendance on the ≈øtate, di≈øturbed with courtiers, di≈øpatches, intrigues of the cabinet, and outcries of a di≈øcontented people loading me with the blame of tho≈øe evils, which you are ≈øen≈øible would never have fallen upon them, had my moderate and more whole≈øome opinion been approved‚ÄîMy di≈ødi≈øcontent under the≈øe vexations, was grown almo≈øt in≈øupportable; and indeed, I mu≈øt very ≈øoon have been borne down under ≈øuch a weight, had not kind providence relea≈øed me; and made my enemies the in≈øtruments of doing me that good, which I was not able to do for my≈øelf. It was a happy coalition‚ñ™ my Lord, that ≈øet me free, and took the burthen upon their own ≈øhoulders.‚ÄîWhat advantage they have got by it. I know not:‚ÄîFor my own part, I have gained a joyous retreat‚ñ™ ≈øurrounded with a charming variety of woods open lawns‚ñ™ and ≈ølow'ry vales in their uncultivated beauty.
Here I rove unattended and free with no circum≈øtance of grandeur, but the con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of a rea≈øonable and immortal being

div.head: A NIGHT PIECE, Or Modern Philo≈øophy, by Mr. Smart.

lg.l: "'TWAS when bright Cynthia with her ≈øilver ear,
Soft ≈øtealing from Endymean's bed,
Had call'd forth every glittering ≈øtar,
And up the a≈øcent of heaven her brilliant ho≈øt had led.
Night with all her Negro train,
Took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the plain;
In an hear≈øe ≈øhe rode reclin'd,
Drawn by Schreech-Owls, ≈ølow and blind.
Clo≈øe to her with printle≈øs feet
Crept ≈øtillne≈øs in a winding ≈øheet.
Next to her deaf ≈øilence was ≈øeen,
Treading on tip-toes o'er the green,
Softly, lightly, gently, ≈øhe trips,
Still holding her finger ≈øeal'd to her lips.
Then came Sleep, ≈øerene and bland,
Bearing the death watch in his hand,
In fluid air around him ≈øwims
A tribe grote≈øque of mimic dreams.
You could not ≈øee a ≈øight,
You could not hear a ≈øound,
But all confe≈øs'd the Night
And horror deepen'd round.
Beneath a Plantain's melancholy ≈øhade,
Sophron the wi≈øe was laid,
And to the an≈øwering wood the≈øe ≈øounds convey'd,
While others toil within the town,
And to fortune ≈ømile or frown,
Fond of trifles, fond of toys,
And married to that woman, noi≈øe:
Sacred wi≈ødom be my care,
And faire≈øt virtue wi≈ødom's heir.
His ≈øpeculations thus the ≈øage begun,
When lo! the neighbouring bell
In ≈øolemn ≈øound ≈øtruck one;‚Äî
He ≈øtarts‚Äîand recollects he was engaged to Nell.
Then up he ≈øprang, nimble and light
And rapt at fair Elenor's door,
He laid a≈øide virtue that night,
And next morn por'd in Plato for more.

div.head: TO THE SOUL. (From the Theological Magazine.)

lg.l: VITAL ≈øpark of heavenly flame,
Quit, oh quit this mortal frame,
Trembling, hoping, lingering flying,
Oh the pain, the bli≈øs of dying!
Cea≈øe, fond nature, cea≈øe thy ≈øtrife
And let me langui≈øh into life:
Hark they whi≈øper; Angels ≈øay,
Si≈øter ≈øpirit come away,
What is this ab≈øorbs me quite?
Steals my ≈øen≈øes, ≈øhuts my ≈øight,
Drowns my ≈øpirits, draws my breath?
Tell me my ≈øoul, can this be death?
The world recedes, it di≈øappears!
Heaven opens on my eyes! my ears
In ≈øounds ≈øeraphic ring:
Lend, lend your wings! I mount I fly!
O grave! where is thy victory?
O Death where is thy ≈øting?

div.head: REMARKABLE LONGING AFTER DEATH
div.p:
YOU have heard, to be ≈øure that S. A≈øhworth is dead I went to ≈øee her almo≈øt every day whil≈øt I was at M‚Äîd; and, I hope, recieved daily improvement by the ≈øight of her. Her behavior, as it was beyond any thing I ever knew, I think, de≈øerves the highe≈øt encomiums, many people after ≈øo long an illne≈øs as hers, was, can bring them≈øelves to be re≈øigned, and ea≈øy with the thought of approaching death; but hers was much more than re≈øignation, ≈øhe expre≈ø≈ø'd the greate≈øt joy imaginable „Äà‚óä„Äâ the thoughts of dying; and her greate≈øt fear was „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øhe ≈øhould live. She was one day
telling her Aunt, what great mercies ≈øhe had received; that ≈øhe had no more pain than what ≈øhe could bear; and added, 'I could bear ten times as much with plea≈øure if I was ≈øure death would come at la≈øt.' Mrs. A≈øhworth a≈øked her, whether, if it were po≈ø≈øible for her to recover‚ñ™ ≈øhe would de≈øire it. O! no, ≈øhe ≈øaid the fear of being ≈ønatched into the world again was her greate≈øt dread, and (≈øays ≈øhe) if you could have any idea of the tran≈øport I feel in the hope of being happy, you could not be ≈øo barbarous to wi≈øh me to live‚ñ™ How charming was this from ≈øo young a per≈øon! She was even, (I think) in≈øtead of being pitied, to be envied in her mo≈øt painful moments,

She was always a≈øking, (when people had been to ≈øee her) what they ≈øaid of her? and the mo≈øt plea≈øing thing you could have told her was, they thought ≈øhe could not live; ≈øometimes when ≈øhe had been a long while without ≈øleep, Mrs‚ñ™ A≈øhworth has been forced to tell her, ≈øhe did not believe ≈øhe could ≈øurvive an hour; with this plea≈øing hope ≈øhe would compo≈øe her≈øelf.‚ÄîWho would not give up all the external charms of wealth or beauty. (which if we happen „Äà‚óä„Äâ to po≈ø≈øe≈øs, we are ≈øo apt to be proud of) for ≈øuch a re≈øolution as this‚ñ™ at a time when our be≈øt earthly enjoyments can be of no advantage to us? I own her behavior made a much greater impre≈ø≈øion on me, than the fine≈øt admonition I ever heard from the pulpit; as example is beyond precept.

When I was with her there appeared ≈øomething
more plea≈øing in death than I had ever before imagined‚ñ™

Every human creature is naturally ≈øhocked at the thought of a di≈ø≈øolution, but it ≈øeemed to give her ≈øo much plea≈øure that it made me reflect on that fine ≈øaying of St. Paul, O Death! where is thy ≈øting! O Grave! where is thy victory? The ≈øting of Death is ≈øin: How true is it! for when combatted by virtue and religion, it lo≈øes all its venom, and we recieve it not as an enemy, nor barely as a relea≈øe from trouble, but as a kind ≈øummons to happine≈øs. I am very willing to believe this was Mrs A≈øhworth's ca≈øe, and that her behavior was not owing to pre≈øumption, or ≈øtupidity; but wholly to con≈øcious innocence.

div.head: MAXIMS FOR THE CONDUCT OF LIFE. TEMPERANCE.
div.p: THE riche≈øt endowments of the mind, are temperence, prudence, and fortitude; Self-denial is the mo≈øt exalted plea≈øure; and the conque≈øt of evil habits, the mo≈øt glorious triumph.
The meane≈øt approach thou can≈øt make to happine≈øs on this ≈øide the grave, is to enjoy under≈øtanding and health.
The≈øe ble≈ø≈øings if thou po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe≈øt, and would≈øt pre≈øerve to old age, avoid the allurements of voluptuou≈øne≈øs, and fly from her temptations.

When ≈øhe ≈øpreadeth her delicacies on the table, when her wine ≈øparkles in the cup, when ≈øhe ≈ømileth upon thee, and per≈øuadeth thee to be joyful and happy: then is the hour of danger, and let rea≈øon ≈øtand firmly on her guard: for if thou hearkene≈øt unto the words of her adver≈øary, thou art decieved and betrayed.
The joy which ≈øhe promi≈øeth changeth to madne≈øs; and her enjoyments lead on to di≈øea≈øes and death.
Ca≈øt thine eyes upon her gue≈øts, who have li≈øtened to her temptations; are they not meagre, are they not ≈øickly, are they not ≈øpiritle≈øs?

Their ≈øhort hours of jollity are followed by tedious days of pain and dejection: her votaries are become her victims, the ju≈øt and natural con≈øequence which God hath ordained in the con≈øtitution of things, for the puni≈øhment of tho≈øe who abu≈øe his gifts. A firm faith is the be≈øt divinity, a good life the be≈øt philo≈øophy, a clear con≈øcience the be≈øt law, hone≈øty the be≈øt policy, and temperance the be≈øt phy≈øic.

div.head: PRUDENCE.
div.p:
JUDGMENT is the throne of prudence, and ≈øilence is its ≈øanctury. It is a maxim of prudence to leave things before they leave us. The true way to advance another's virtue, is to follow it; and the be≈øt way to decry down another's vice, is to decline it. A warm heart requires a cool head. Courage without conduct,
is, like fancy without judgment; all ‚Ä¢ ail, and no balla≈øt. Put a bridle on thy tongue; ≈øet a guard before thy lips, le≈øt the words of thine own mouth de≈øtroy thy peace.
Boa≈øt not of thy≈øelf, for it ≈øhall bring contempt upon thee, neither deride another for it is dangerous.
A bitter je≈øt is the poi≈øon of friend≈øhip, and he that cannot re≈øtrain his tonge; ≈øhall have trouble.

Furni≈øh thy≈øelf with the proper accommodations belonging to thy condition but ≈øpend not the utmo≈øt of what thou can≈øt afford, that the providence of thy youth may be a comfort to thy old age. Let not pro≈øperity put out the eyes of circum≈øpection, nor abundance cut off the hands of frugality, he that too much indulges in the ≈øuperfluities of life, ≈øhall live to lament the want of it's nece≈ø≈øaries. From the experience of others do thou learn wi≈ødom, and from their failings correct thine own faults. Charity obliges not to mi≈øtru≈øt a man, prudence not to tru≈øt him before we know him.
When thou ha≈øt proved a man to be hone≈øt, look him up in thine heart as a trea≈øure, regard him as a jewel of ine≈øtimable value.

Refu≈øe the favours of a mercenary man, they will be a ≈ønare unto thee, thou ≈øhalt never be quit of the obligation. U≈øe not to day what to-morrow may
want; neither leave that to hazard which fore≈øight may provide for, or can prevent.
Yet expect not even from prudence infallible ≈øucce≈øs; for the day knoweth not what the night may bring forth.
The fool is not always unfortunate, nor the wi≈øe man always ≈øucce≈øsful.

div.head: FORTITUDE.
div.p: PERILS, mi≈øfortunes, pain, and injury, are more or le≈øs the lot of every man that cometh into the world.
In human life there is a con≈øtant change of fortune, and it is unrea≈øonable to expect from the common fate. Life it≈øelf decays, and all things are daily on the change.

Imprint this maxim deeply in your mind, that there is nothing certain in this human and mortal ≈øtate; by which means you will avoid being tran≈øported with pro≈øperity and being dejected in adver≈øity.
A wi≈øe man ≈øtands firm in all extremities, and bears the lot of his humanity with a divine temper.
He ≈øuffers not his happine≈øs to depend on her ≈ømiles, and with her frowns he will not be di≈ømayed.
Under the pre≈ø≈øure of his misfortunes, his calmne≈øs alleviates their weight, and his con≈øtancy ≈øhall ≈øurmount them.

A peaceful con≈øcience hone≈øt thoughts, virtuous actions, and an indifference for ca≈øual events, are ble≈ø≈øings
without end or mea≈øure; this con≈øummate ≈øtate of felicity is a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the dictates of right nature; the foundation of its wi≈ødom and virtue; the knowledge of what we ought do, and the conformity of the will to that knowledge. Every virtue gives a man a degree of felicity in ≈øome kind: hone≈øty gives a man a good report; ju≈øtice, e≈øtimation; prudence, re≈øpect‚ñ™ courte≈øy and liberallity, affection; temperence, gives health; fortitude, a quiet mind, not to be moved by any adver≈øity.

Virtue is a ble≈ø≈øing, which man alone po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes, and no other creature has any title to but him≈øelf. All is nothing without her, and ≈øhe alone is all. The other ble≈ø≈øings of this life, are often times imaginary: She is always real‚ÄîShe is the life and crown of all perfections.

div.head: DESIDERATA. (From the Philo≈øophical and Mechanical Magazines)

p.hi: WHEREAS there are various things, which might ju≈øtly be ≈øuppo≈øed ≈øolvable, by the application of ≈øome of the numerous experiments in natural as well as moral philo≈øophy, which have not been as yet inve≈øtigated, or in the lea≈øt enquired into.

I now ≈øtate to the public the following que≈øtions which I humbly concieve‚ñ™ ≈øhould they be thoroughly traced out‚ñ™ and completely, and ≈øatisfactorily an≈øwered would be of ine≈øtimable and immen≈øe value to mankind.

div.p:
1≈øt. AS there are, doubtle≈øs ≈øundry mines of gold
within the limits of the three New-England ≈øtates. By what means and mea≈øures can they be ab≈øolutely found and obtained.
2nd. What machine can be con≈øtructed to plow in any hard‚ñ™ ≈øtony, or ‚Ä¢ ooty ground, with dexterity and di≈øpatch without any kind of animal team.

3rd. What method can be taken to make wood of every kind grow in and near all the mo≈øt populous towns, to be within „Äà‚óä„Äâ year, hence, as thick and as large as it ever has been at any one period of time ≈øince the year of our Lord fifteen hundred.

4th. By what parts can a great plenty of good manure be forewith produced, with great cheapne≈øs and facility, for all our good old fields, which are very ea≈øy to plow; but will not bear a good crop by rea≈øon of poverty.

10th. What medical, philo≈øophical, co≈ømitical, or rational preparation and applications will ab≈øolutely drive far away every kind of ≈øorrow and pain‚ñ™ forever from a man, and at the ≈øame time yield him that cerdain‚ñ™ complete, fini≈øhed, and durable happine≈øs and felicity, which ≈øhall not fail him in the lea≈øt degree for „Äà‚óä„Äâ five hundred years.

lg.l: WANTON zephyrs ≈øoftly blowing
Watching, catching, whi≈øpering, going;
Bear in ≈øighs, my ≈øoul away;
Tell Ormondo what I feel,
Tell him how his chains I wear,
Tell him all my grief and care,
Gently ≈øtealing,
And revealing,
More of love than I can ≈øay.
OH fountains! when in you ≈øhall I,
Ea≈ø'd of unpeaceful thoughts my≈øelf e≈øpy,
O fields! Oh woods! when ≈øhall I be made,
The happy tenant of your ≈øhade!
Here's the ≈øpring head of plea≈øures flood,
Where all the riches lie.
That ≈øhe has coin'd and ≈øtamp't for good,
To charm the mind as well as eye;
Pride and ambition here;
Only in far-fetch'd metaphors appear;
Here's nought but winds‚ñ™ can hurtful murmurs ≈øcatter,
And nought but echo flatter.
The God's when they de≈øcended hither,
From Heaven, did always choo≈øe their way
And therefore we may boldly ≈øay,
That is the way too thither.
